content:
Edit in Constraints:
- 22 ≤ i ≤ 43
+ 22 ≤ length of i ≤ 43

Comment on shortest mode:
It seems to me that the given string must be in lowercase, but this is not mentioned in the statement.
I believe it is better to mention that somewhere in the statement/constraints.


Anyway, a nice puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It seems like a well crafted idea.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting puzzle, great for shortest.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very well explained and solvable very fast.
+ Xzoky174 already made a lot of fun Clash of Code

This is a fun clash.
Couple of things
1.  I changed the statement a bit, to hopefully make things a little clearer.
2. Your test cases and validators need to check for the same condition. For example, if Test 1 is a pangram, Validator 1 should be too.
Fix this and I'll approve the clash.

Perhaps for pangram, you should also the alphabet sorted by their first appearance  in the string (i.e for "the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog" the output would be "Pangram t h e q u i c k b r o w n f x j m p s r l a z y d g" )

Perhaps for pangram, you should also the alphabet sorted by their first appearance  in the string (i.e for "the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog" the output would be "Pangram t h e q u i c k b r o w n f x j m p s r l a z y d g" )

Explain what a pangram is in your statement, and make the output clearer ( i.e remaining characters separated by space ).

ig you can also make/modify 1 or 2 test cases with 1 letter/100 letters so the constraints look nicer.

Also not the best idea for reverse considering you just gave the answer straight away in the first test case

1.
`print('false')`
gives you 75% in this task.
Please consider changing your output to something more complex.

2.
The problem is quite hard for "Reverse" given that you need to guess all conditions (case insensitive, special characters, etc.)

3. Don't leave the "Constraints" section empty. You can add the boundaries for the input string there. It will help people to solve it in languages where you need to define the buffer to read a string (C, Pascal, etc.).

4. You have a typo in the title.
Thanks for your feedback! I'll make the necessary changes.
I've just added a constraint on what characters the input strings may contain. :)

Now that the output in case of not a pangram is quite explicit, I think this may also be a nice Reverse challenge too.
Maybe just add some test for how to handle the different cases.
